title: 103_hr3028
content: The "Health Care and Housing for Women and Children Act of 1993" includes a program for maternal health certificates for eligible pregnant women. The "Health Care and Housing for Women and Children Act of 1993" establishes a program to provide maternal health certificates for eligible pregnant women to cover expenses at maternity and housing services facilities. Pregnant women with an annual income not exceeding 175 percent of the official poverty line are eligible to receive these certificates. The program established under the "Health Care and Housing for Women and Children Act of 1993" provides maternal health certificates for eligible pregnant women with income below 175 percent of the poverty line. The income of an estranged spouse is not included in the individual's income calculation. Participation in the AFDC program is not required for eligibility. The program provides maternal health certificates for eligible pregnant women with income below 175 percent of the poverty line. Eligibility is not based on receiving aid under the State plan for aid to families with dependent children. The certificate can cover expenses at a maternity housing facility up to $100 per day of services provided. A maternity housing facility approved by the State provides residence and supportive services for pregnant women, including room and board, medical care, counseling, nutrition services, and education. The maternity housing facility approved by the State offers prenatal care, childbirth education, family counseling, adoption counseling, vocational and educational services, and transportation assistance for pregnant women. Authorization of appropriations includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 1993. Authorization of appropriations for the maternity housing facility includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 1993, $75,000,000 for fiscal year 1994, and $100,000,000 for fiscal year 1995. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will establish a grant program to assist eligible nonprofit entities in rehabilitating existing structures for maternity housing and services facilities. Grants will be provided to entities that submit applications meeting specified requirements. SEC. 203. GRANT LIMITATIONS. Grants under this title are limited to $1,000,000 per eligible nonprofit entity per fiscal year, with a maximum of one grant allowed. The Secretary may not award grants to more than 100 entities in a fiscal year. Recipients must use the funds for acquiring or rehabilitating existing structures for maternity housing and services facilities. The Secretary requires eligible nonprofit entities receiving grants to submit reports detailing their activities. Definitions are provided in Section 205. The term "eligible nonprofit entity" refers to a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has applied for a grant. A "maternity housing and services facility" is a state-approved residence for at least 4 pregnant women during and after pregnancy. The Secretary may determine a program for pregnant women providing supportive services such as room and board, medical care, counseling, nutrition services, education on prenatal care, childbirth, and motherhood, family counseling, adoption counseling, and vocational/educational counseling. The Secretary may establish a program for pregnant women offering supportive services like transportation, vocational/educational counseling, and other appropriate services. A pregnant woman is defined as a woman with one or more fetuses in utero. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Authorization of appropriations for this title includes $25,000,000 for fiscal year 1993, $40,000,000 for fiscal year 1994, and $60,000,000 for fiscal year 1995.
